article.p: First, a guaranteed nonsingular 5\times 5 matrix, created at random.

statement.p: Augment with the zero vector, using the matrix method .augment() and the vector constructor zero_vector(QQ, 5). Then row-reduce to use Definition NM. Or instead, do not augment and apply Theorem NMRRI.

Build some random vectors with random_vector(QQ, 5), augment the matrix and row-reduce. There will always be a unique solution to the linear system represented by the augmented matrix. This is Theorem NMUS.

article.p: Now, a carefully crafted singular matrix.

statement.p: Augment with the zero vector and row-reduce (Definition NM), or don't augment and row-reduce (Theorem NMRRI).]

article.p: A null space is called a right kernel in Sage. It's description contains a lot of things we do not understand yet.

statement.p: But we can test membership in the null space, which is the most basic property of a set. Try u in NS and then repeat with v.
